bug.author: aaron276h
bug.summary: Multi machine example crashes when using GLOO controller.
bug.description:
Environment:
Framework: (TensorFlow, Keras, PyTorch, MXNet) TF Framework version: 1.14.0 Horovod version: Latest: 83eaa163b395ae8866a404f94facf82cc8127642 MPI version: N/A CUDA version: 10 NCCL version: 2.4.7 Python version: 3.6 OS and version: ubuntu 16.04 GCC version: 4.8
Bug report: After installing Horovod without MPI (using GLOO controller), when I run the tensorflow_keras_mnist example on multiple machines I get an error. When run on multi-gpus within the same machine it works. Note: Running this inside docker containers, and have set up SSH between nodes. Have also ran export HOROVOD_GLOO_IFACE=ens13. Also on a related question, why do we need to support SSH between machines when using a non MPI controller? <denchmark-code>root@aaron-host-1:/# NCCL_DEBUG=INFO horovodrun -np 2 -H aaron-host-1:1,aaron-host-3:1 -p 12345 python /home/aaronharlap/repos/horovod/examples/tensorflow_keras_mnist.py Thu Aug 29 13:34:16 2019[0]<stderr>:WARNING: Logging before flag parsing goes to stderr. comments.comment: Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/aaron276h>@aaron276h</denchmark-link> , thanks for raising this issue. Looks like this is due to running on a single GPU with multiple machines. A quick workaround in the short term would be to run on more than one GPU per machine if available. We put in a fix a while back in Horovod to support running with 1 GPU (world size = 1), but this appears to be coming from the local communicators on each machine, which form rings among all the GPUs on a single host. So the world size = 1 check is failing. The best fix here will be to fix this upstream in Gloo (<denchmark-link:https://github.com/facebookincubator/gloo/issues/209>facebookincubator/gloo#209</denchmark-link> ), which I'll prioritize for this sprint. To answer your other question, we use SSH to launch subprocesses on different machines from the horovodrun application. We also use SSH to determine common interfaces.

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tgaddair>@tgaddair</denchmark-link> thanks for the quick reply! I tried out running with 4 GPUs per machine and got a diferrent error message: <denchmark-code>root@aaron-host-1:~# NCCL_DEBUG=INFO horovodrun -np 8 -H aaron-host-1:4,aaron-host-3:4 -p 12345 python /home/aaronharlap/repos/horovod/examples/tensorflow_keras_mnist.py Thu Aug 29 16:41:02 2019[3]<stderr>:WARNING: Logging before flag parsing goes to stderr. Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/aaron276h>@aaron276h</denchmark-link> , I think I found the source of the error. I've updated the branch if you'd like to try installing it again: <denchmark-code>pip install --no-cache-dir git+https://github.com/horovod/horovod.git@gloo_size_1 </denchmark-code>

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/tgaddair>@tgaddair</denchmark-link> Using the new install running after installing works for both 2 machine with 1 GPU each, and 2 machine with 8 GPUs each. Thanks so much for your help! I was wondering, are there any known issues we should keep in mind if we plan to use Horovod with GLOO instead of MPI?

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/aaron276h>@aaron276h</denchmark-link> , that's great! Happy to help. At the moment there aren't any major issues (besides this one) that we're aware of with Gloo. The only caveats I can think of are:
Only works on Linux currently (no Mac OS for now). Does not support hierarchical allreduce / hierarchical allgather options yet (only needed for very large cluster setups). MPI will outperform Gloo for CPU operations due to Gloo's lack of shared memory and network interface load balancing support. But when using NCCL, we do not observe any performance difference between MPI and Gloo. Progress bars may render incorrectly when using standalone Keras (progress bars work with tf.keras).
